head.title: A New School Rule: Play With Your Food!

hedline.hl1: A New School Rule: Play With Your Food!

abstract.p: Jack Kloppenburg letter on usng food items in classroom to help children learn

block.p: Re ''Snack Foods Become Stars of Books for Children'' (front page, Sept. 22):
Re ''Snack Foods Become Stars of Books for Children'' (front page, Sept. 22):

With primers like the ''Kellogg's Froot Loops! Counting Fun Book'' in schools, our children learn to consume as they learn how to count. The pedagogy is sound, although the use of junk food is perverse.

Last week, I brought a selection of home-grown tomatoes into my daughter's first-grade class. We counted 11 different varieties, including Brandywine, Green Zebra, Peacevine and that incomparable burst of flavor that is Sungold.

I was surprised but elated at how enthusiastically 18 children devoured three pounds of unfamiliar produce and clamored for more. If children could learn to count with tomatoes rather than M & M's, perhaps one out of 10 American children would not be obese. Our educational system ought to develop healthy citizens, not unhealthy consumers.
JACK KLOPPENBURG JR. Madison, Wis., Sept. 24, 2000
